issue.title: Add CompletionStage assertion

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
#### Summary
AbstractCompletableFutureAssert has methods to run assertions on CompletableFutures.
However, in any given unit test, the given CompletableFuture might not have completed yet, causing the test to be brittle. The exception report can be quite confusing because between the test  failure and the printing of the test error, the future might complete. So even a test asserting isDone() can fail with a message showing a done future.

Coding around this is ugly. Would be real nice if assertj had some waiting (with timeout, with default timeout) function embedded.

Also would be nice if this would work with CompletionStages as well.

Something like
```
CompletionStage<Foo> fooStage = getFoo();
assertThat(fooStage).completesWithin(1000).hasFailedWithThrowableThat()
```

Note: I think the awaitility library could also help, but so far did not use it. Could be this is better solved by using both awaitility and assertj.

issue.title: CompletionStage asserts about failed state should fail when not Done, and only join() else

labels.name: status: pending investigation
labels.description: An issue that needs additional investigation

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
`hasFailed()` assertion currently passes when the Future/CompletionStage is not yet done, causing brittle tests and race conditions. `hasFailedWithThrowableThat()` on the other hand joins, so it's also an inconsistency.   hasFailedWithThrowableThat() should only join() when done. joining else may cause infinitely running tests, which is undesirable even if it's the original test cases fault.

* [x]  hasFailed() should fail when not done.
* [ ] hasNotFailed() should fail when not done.
* [x]  hasFailedWithThrowableThat() should only join() when done. 

Discussed in #1010

issue.title: assertThat with CompletionStage is not waiting CompletableFuture to complete

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

body: Sorry for digging up an old issue, but what happened to `failsWithin()`?
`succeedsWithin` has been added, let's finish this issue by adding `failsWithin`

@hadrienk I feel the readability is better with this option, WDYT?
```java
assertThat(tokenFuture).failsWithin(duration) // and/or failsWithin(timeout, unit)           
                       .withMessage("boom!")
                       .withNoCause();
```
more importantly, what would be `failsWithin` semantics?  

Is that any of the exception thrown while resolving the future (ie. InterruptedException | ExecutionException | TimeoutException | CancellationException) or simply TimeoutException? 

In completable future assertions, we have the `hasFailed` assertion which means "completed exceptionally but not cancelled".
moving this issue to 3.18.0 until we decide on the expected behaviour in order not to block the 3.17.0 release

I agree that would be the most natural.

I remember spending quite a bit of time trying to get the `CompletableFuture` assertions right and not being fully happy with them but at the time that was the best I could think of, in hindsight I would probably do it differently today, I'll consider deprecating `hasFailed` as part of this piece of work.

`assertThat(tokenFuture).timesoutWithin(duration);` reads nicely but the other a bit less,  `isInterruptedWithin` sounds better.

I see the usefulness of `timesoutWithin` but the other ones don't seem to me as useful, I would wait for other users to request them.
